text.p: Here are highlights of stories in Romania's press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy:
Business:
CAPITAL
- Romania's economy is on the brink of collapse, the paper said.
- Romania's reform programme is back to square one, the paper said.
- The government decided to take a tough stand against companies which failed to pay their debts and taxes.
- The government will cut subsidies to the farming sector, the paper said.
- The government might lose parliament's support if it implements unpopular measures, Transport Minister Traian Basescu says in an interview.
ADEVARUL
- Bucharest's Romaero SA aircraft maker signed an accord with Lockheed Martin Corp to open aircraft maintenance and repair centre.
CURIERUL NATIONAL
- The leu's stability could be achieved by controlling inflation, deficits and losses, the paper quotes central bank governor Mugur Isarescu as saying.
- Defence Minister Victor Babiuc threatened to resign if the defence budget is lower than 3.0 percent of the GDP, the paper says.
EVENIMENTUL ZILEI
- The government tried to persuade international lenders to accept its plans to cut profit taxes starting February.
ROMANIA LIBERA
- The 1997 social protection budget will account for some 10 percent of the GDP, the paper said.
General
ADEVARUL
- Miners' leader Miron Cosma told a Bucharest court he was not responsible for the 1991 riots which ousted Romania's first post-communist government.
- The National Liberal Party (Democratic Convention) will ask parliament to pass a bill allowing Romanians access' to their former secret police files.
- Magistrates at the Bucharest municipal court continue their strike protesting against poor working conditions.
EVENIMENTUL ZILEI
- Police investigations showed that the Ukrainian vessel detained in the Danube port of Galati last week was laden with 27 tonnes of smuggled cigarettes.
ROMANIA LIBERA
- Some 1,140 hectares of arable land in Insula Mare a Brailei were allegedly illegally distributed to senior members of the former ruling Party of Social Democracy, the paper said. ($=5,978)
-- Bucharest Newsroom 40-1 3120264
